definition: Comprehensive, documented, enterprise-wide program of administrative, technical, and physical safeguards designed to protect customer information security, confidentiality, integrity, and availability against reasonably foreseeable threats. Core requirement of GLBA Safeguards Rule with nine mandatory elements.
official_description: GLBA Section 501(b) and implementing Safeguards Rule 16 CFR Parts 314.3 and 314.4 require financial institutions under FTC jurisdiction to develop, implement, and maintain written information security program. Program must: (1) ensure security and confidentiality of customer information, (2) protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to security or integrity of such information, (3) protect against unauthorized access to or use of customer information that could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to customers. Program must be comprehensive addressing all aspects of information security enterprise-wide, coordinated among all business units and departments, continuously monitored and tested, regularly updated based on risk assessments and testing results, appropriate to institution's size, complexity, nature and scope of activities, and sensitivity of customer information handled. Program must include nine mandatory elements per 16 CFR 314.4: (1) Qualified Individual designation with appropriate authority and oversight, (2) Periodic written risk assessments identifying foreseeable threats and safeguard sufficiency, (3) Safeguard design and implementation addressing administrative, technical, physical protections, (4) Continuous monitoring and testing including vulnerability assessment and penetration testing, (5) Security awareness training for all personnel, (6) Oversight of third-party service providers with customer information access, (7) Regular updates to program based on monitoring, risk assessment, and threat landscape, (8) Incident response plan addressing detection through post-incident review, (9) Annual written report to board or senior management. Program must have board or senior officer approval, oversight, and resource allocation. Program must be documented in writing with policies, procedures, and implementation guidance. Program effectiveness subject to FTC examination and enforcement.

definition: Organizational and administrative safeguards component of GLBA information security program comprising policies, procedures, personnel security, access controls, authorization, and personnel management to establish governance and control framework for information security.
official_description: Administrative safeguards represent organizational and governance safeguards supporting technical and physical protections. 16 CFR 314.4(c) requires administrative safeguards including: policies and procedures addressing GLBA requirements; personnel security requirements; access control policies based on need-to-know and least privilege; authorization and approval procedures; user provisioning and deprovisioning; periodic access reviews; job responsibilities and segregation of duties; incident response procedures; change management; vendor management; data governance; awareness and training (Element 5). Administrative safeguards provide foundation for institution's security culture and governance. Must address all personnel: employees, contractors, temporary workers, vendors. Policies documented in writing, communicated to personnel, enforced consistently. Policies reviewed and updated annually or upon significant changes. Violation of administrative safeguards creates vulnerability to unauthorized access, data breaches, fraud.
applicable_to: All financial institutions under Safeguards Rule; all personnel with customer information access; all departments and business units; all levels from board to operational staff; applies to employees, contractors, temporary workers, vendors; all geographic locations; all systems and data handling customer information

definition: Technical security controls component of GLBA information security program comprising encryption, multi-factor authentication, system hardening, intrusion detection, vulnerability management, application security, and monitoring systems protecting customer information from unauthorized access and cyber threats.
official_description: Technical safeguards represent technology-based security controls protecting customer information and systems. 16 CFR 314.4(c) requires technical safeguards including: encryption of customer information at rest (AES-256 minimum) and in transit (TLS 1.2+ minimum); multi-factor authentication for system access; system hardening and secure configuration; patch management; vulnerability identification and remediation; intrusion detection/prevention systems; audit logging and monitoring; secure development practices; endpoint security; network security; application security. Technical safeguards must address all systems storing, processing, or transmitting customer information. Must be regularly tested and updated to address emerging threats. Technical safeguards combined with administrative safeguards and physical safeguards provide layered defense (defense-in-depth) protecting customer information.

definition: Physical security controls component of GLBA information security program comprising facility access controls, environmental controls, media security, secure disposal, and physical monitoring protecting customer information facilities and data storage from unauthorized physical access and damage.
official_description: Physical safeguards represent non-technological security measures protecting physical facilities, equipment, and media containing customer information. 16 CFR 314.4(c) requires physical safeguards including: facility access controls, environmental controls, media security and proper disposal. Physical safeguards must address: data center access restrictions, office space access controls, visitor management, surveillance systems, alarm systems, secure storage areas, environmental protection (fire, water, temperature, humidity), media disposal procedures. Physical safeguards combined with administrative and technical safeguards provide comprehensive protection (defense-in-depth). Small institutions may implement scaled versions appropriate to risk and complexity.
